chapter.title: Advanced topics
chapter.subtitle: Building and running &C2; from source code
chapter.para: This chapter discusses more advanced usage scenarios of &C2; such as running &C2; applications in Eclipse and building &C2; from source code.

section.title: Running &DCW; in Eclipse IDE
section.para: To run &DCW; in Eclipse IDE (version 3.4 or higher required):

para.link: Set up &C2; source code in your Eclipse IDE.

listitem.para: Choose Window > Preferences and then Run/Debug > String substitution. Add a temp_workspaces variable pointing to a an existing disk directory where the Workbench's workspace should be created.
Choose Run > Run Configurations... from the main menu and run the Workbench configuration.

para.link: Set up &C2; source code in your Eclipse IDE.

listitem.para: Choose Run > External Tools > External Tools Configurations... from the main menu and run the Web Application Setup [carrot2] configuration. This will preprocess various configuration files required by the web application.
Choose Run > Run Configurations... from the main menu and run the Web Application Runner [carrot2] configuration.
Point your browser to http://localhost:8080 to access the running web application.

section.title: Building &C2; from source code
section.para: To build &C2; applications from source code, you will need Java Software Development Kit (Java SDK) version 1.8 or higher and Apache Ant version 1.9.3 or higher. You can chcek out the latest &C2; source code using git:

listitem.para: Download Eclipse Target Platform from and extract to some local folder.

Copy local.properties.example from &C2; checkout folder to local.properties in the same folder. In local.properties edit the target.platform property to point to the Eclipse Target Platform you have downloaded.

important.para: The folder pointed to by target.platform must have the eclipse/ folder inside.

listitem.para: You may also change the configs property to match the platform you want to build &DCW; for or rely on auto-detection.

Run:
ant workbench
to build &DCW; binaries.
Go to the tmp/ workbench/ tmp/ carrot2-workbench folder in the &C2; checkout dir and run &DCW;.

Run:
ant webapp
in the main &PROD; checkout directory.
Go to the tmp/webapp/ folder in the &C2; checkout dir where you will find the web application WAR file.

section.title: Working with HTTP proxies
section.para: If your server or development machine connects to HTTP servers via a HTTP proxy, you can most of &C2; document source implementations to take this information into account by defining the following global system properties:

listitem.para: URL of the HTTP proxy (numeric or full address, but without the port number).

section.para: Two sources that currently do not support the above properties are: Bing3WebDocumentSource and OpenSearchDocumentSource.

section.title: HTTP BASIC or DIGEST authentication
section.para: If your document source initiates HTTP connections to a server protected with BASIC or DIGEST HTTP authentication, you will have to pass the username and password to the application so that such connections can be established. Define the following global system properties (they are picked up once, when the Controller is created):

listitem.para: Username for BASIC or DIGEST authentication.
Password for BASIC or DIGEST authentication.

section.para: Note that, in general, it's better not to have any HTTP authentication at all since it's a very weak form of protection anyway and only increases network traffic (two HTTP requests may have to be made in order to fetch the remote resource).
